nytimes_articles.headline: CHRONICLE
nytimes_articles.abstract: "What is a garden for?"    NIGEL NICOLSON, the British writer, politician and publisher and the son of Vita Sackville-West and Harold Nicolson, will muse upon that question tomorrow at the Parrish Art Museum in Southampton, L.I. But he would not give even a hint about his lecture in advance.

nytimes_articles.headline: Review/Philharmonic; Memories of Bernstein, As Musician and Man
nytimes_articles.abstract: A mayoral proclamation honoring Leonard Bernstein and the New York Philharmonic was posted near the entry doors of Avery Fisher Hall on Wednesday night. In the lobby, under a glass case, was Bernstein's desk, complete with pencil stubs, reading glasses, a checkbook and an open pack of Tums. In another display was Bernstein's scribbled account of a dream along with his score of Mahler's Sixth Symphony (a bumper sticker across its opening pages proclaimed, "Mahler Grooves"). And inside the hall, Leonard Slatkin led an all-Bernstein program, part of a weeklong series of events the Philharmonic has organized titled "Remembering Lenny."

nytimes_articles.headline: 1893:Murder in Siam : IN OUR PAGES: 100, 75 AND 50 YEARS AGO
nytimes_articles.abstract: PARIS - A French agent has been murdered in Siam, and the French Government has at once ordered the Naval Squadron in the Far East to make a cruise off the coast. Details of the murder are not to hand, but ambush and treason are suspected. The French pres

nytimes_articles.headline: Love at 40: Tennis, Anyone?
nytimes_articles.abstract: IS it possible to date the start of an addiction? To pinpoint the exact moment when a person goes from not hooked to hooked?   In my case, I like to think it was that bright June day in 1984 when my friend Alma lured me out onto a tennis court and I hit the first of what has since become millions upon millions of tennis balls. But psychologically, the ground had probably been prepared earlier by a journalist I knew back then. He had this theory that most of us operated, all our lives long, on skills we had acquired by the age of 22. As the years wore on, he maintained, we might refine those skills, but few of us actually decided, one middle-aged morning, to take up hang-gliding, for example, or learn Greek.

nytimes_articles.headline: Three Tied At 4 Under After Day 1 Of Open
nytimes_articles.abstract: With its only defense the inherent difficulty of its classic design, Baltusrol bent to the breaking point today as Joey Sindelar, Scott Hoch and Craig Parry all shot four-under-par 66's to share the first-round lead of the 93d United States Open.   On a windless, warm day that did nothing to thicken the relatively sparse rough bordering the fairways and greens, none of the leaders spoke of flawless ball-striking or brilliant putting. That fact supported the notion that the championship 72-hole scoring record will be broken for the third successive United States Open held at Baltusrol.

nytimes_articles.headline: Pop/Jazz; Evolution and Festivals And Finding the Fittest
nytimes_articles.abstract: The JVC Jazz Festival, which opens tonight at Carnegie Hall, has traditionally been the reef that attracts all the fish. Sometimes the reef has been made of coral, other times junk. But it's always been a behemoth, bringing in tourists from all over the world. Though it has long lost the function of mirroring trends, it's still an immensely important event, partly because it stimulates other festivals. For the last five years, the Knitting Factory in the East Village has run its downtown version of the JVC Jazz Festival, called What Is Jazz?   This year's JVC Jazz Festival, as always, features some of the best improvisers in the jazz tradition, including Joe Henderson, Wynton Marsalis, Gerry Mulligan, Betty Carter, Elvin Jones, Freddie Hubbard, Benny Golson, Gary Bartz and many more. And it's heavy on singers, including Lena Horne, Cassandra Wilson, Anita O'Day, Ms. Carter and Mel Torme. But gone are the late-afternoon solo piano concerts, and to find any evidence of the jazz renaissance of the last decade, one has to search the fine print for sidemen and opening acts.

nytimes_articles.headline: The Second City Is Getting Ready For a Third Title
nytimes_articles.abstract: Magic Johnson played cards with Michael Jordan on Tuesday. Johnson saw the look in Jordan's eyes. He heard the determination in Jordan's voice. He saw the disgust on Jordan's face when he read articles that suggested he had been bothered by Kevin Johnson's defense on Sunday.   That's when Johnson knew Jordan would play with fury on Wednesday night.

nytimes_articles.headline: Meter by Meter, a Rhythm Is Restored
nytimes_articles.abstract: If Ana Fidelia Quirot, Cuba's 800-meter Olympic bronze medalist, never wins another race, the national hero who had been known for her speed will still receive at least as much recognition for her heart.   Ana Fidelia, as she is universally known in her homeland in that ultimate index of sports stardom -- first-name recognition -- suffered first- and second-degree burns over 38 percent of her body in a fire at her home in Havana last January.

nytimes_articles.headline: Corrections
nytimes_articles.abstract: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about a new peace plan for Bosnia and Herzegovina referred incorrectly in some editions to the country, besides Serbia, that is seen by the Muslim-dominated Bosnian Government as most likely to annex parts of Bosnian territory. It is Croatia.

nytimes_articles.headline: How to Shoot Baseball: Use Camera, Not Mouth
nytimes_articles.abstract: IT'S the heart of June and the clubhouses are remarkably free of scandal. John Franco has tantrums. As a Met, he should. Steinbrenner threatens to move the Yanks out of the Bronx. He always has. What else is new?   You might ask the gentleman with his face behind a Nikon, crouched just off the field between home plate and first base at every game in Yankee or Shea Stadium.

nytimes_articles.headline: Officer Is Arrested In Queens Drug Sting
nytimes_articles.abstract: A New York City police officer who the authorities say offered his protection to drug couriers has been indicted on charges of bribery and related offenses, the Queens District Attorney's office announced yesterday.   The officer, Andre McDougal of the 101st Precinct in Far Rockaway, was arrested on May 26 during a sting operation in which he escorted an undercover officer who claimed to be transporting $100,000 in drug money, the authorities said.

nytimes_articles.headline: Senate Gives (and Takes) $1.2 Billion for Pentagon
nytimes_articles.abstract: The Senate voted 95 to 0 today to give the Pentagon $1.2 billion it had not requested for military programs but to cut other programs by the same amount.   The Senate Appropriations Committee had originally voted to add the spending, which would have increased the Federal budget deficit. But Senators retreated because of the political climate, which seems to demand deficit cutting.

nytimes_articles.headline: PRESIDENT SOFTENS OPPOSITION BY U.S. TO DIVIDED BOSNIA
nytimes_articles.abstract: President Clinton signaled tonight that the United States might accept a partition of Bosnia that would allow the Serbs to keep land they seized by force, provided that Bosnian Muslims and Croats agreed to such a plan.   Mr. Clinton, speaking in the East Room of the White House at his first evening news conference, said he still preferred a "multi-ethnic state" in Bosnia. But he said for the first time that "if the parties themselves agree, genuinely and honestly agree, the United States would have to look very seriously" at the three-way partition plan proposed by the Presidents of Serbia and Croatia.  [ Excerpts from the news conference, page A19. ] Only Practical Solution    Until tonight, the Clinton Administration said it would never endorse such an alteration of internationally recognized borders by force. But American officials now acknowledge that such partition is probably the only practical solution, given that neither Washington nor its European allies are ready to use force to hold Bosnia together and that the Bosnian Muslims do not have the power to do so alone.

guardian_articles.headline: 700 mourn teenager killed in race attack

nytimes_articles.headline: Hearing Set on July 20 On Nominee for Court
nytimes_articles.abstract: The Senate Judiciary Committee today set July 20 for the start of confirmation hearings on the nomination of Judge Ruth Bader Ginsburg to the Supreme Court.   The announcement by the committee chairman, Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr., Democrat of Delaware, means that Judge Ginsburg could be sworn in as an Associate Justice by the first week of August. That would allow her to begin familiarizing herself with the Supreme Court's voluminous caseload in advance of the fall term, which begins Oct. 4.

nytimes_articles.headline: PLAN SET TO SECURE 747'S JET ENGINES
nytimes_articles.abstract: The Boeing Company has proposed modifications to all 747 jumbo jets to make engines less likely to fall off in flight.    Engine mounts on the four-engine 747's have come under scrutiny since they were implicated in the crashes of an El Al cargo jet in Amsterdam on Oct. 4 and of a China Airlines cargo plane in Taiwan on Dec. 21, 1991. In both crashes, investigators said, the two engines on the right wing fell off.  But regulatory agencies have not determined the causes of the two crashes.

nytimes_articles.headline: Theater in Review
nytimes_articles.abstract: Brave Smiles Another Lesbian Tragedy  New York Theater Workshop 769 East Fourth Street East Village Through Sunday Written by the Five Lesbian Brothers: Maureen Angelos, Babs Davy, Dominique Dibbell, Peg Healey and Lisa Kron; scripted by Ms. Dibbell and Ms. Healey; directed by Kate Stafford; set by Jamie Leo; costumes by Susan Young; lighting by Diana Arecco; sound by Ms. Healey; company manager, Heidi Sama Blackwell; musical arrangements, Tom Judson and the Brave Smiles Orchestra. Presented by New York Theater Workshop, James C. Nicola, artistic director; Nancy Kassak Diekmann, managing director. WITH: Maureen Angelos, Babs Davy, Dominique Dibbell, Peg Healey and Lisa Kron.

nytimes_articles.headline: Diana in Philadelphia
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor:   "In Statues of Women, Numbers Aren't the Story" by David Sidorsky (letter, June 5) states of the statue of Diana atop the old Madison Square Garden: "The original disappeared with the demolition of Stanford White's Garden at Madison Square."

nytimes_articles.headline: Observer; Pure Only Of Heart
nytimes_articles.abstract: Reasons I cannot be on the Supreme Court:   1. Once tore up a parking ticket, thus becoming a scofflaw.   2. Regularly exceed the 55-mile-per-hour speed limit on Interstate 78, thus flagrantly exhibiting contempt for the law.

nytimes_articles.headline: Corrections
nytimes_articles.abstract: An obituary yesterday about Doxey A. Wilkerson, an educator who lived in Norwalk, Conn., referred incorrectly to two organizations for which he worked. They are the Jefferson School of Social Science and the American Jewish Congress, not the Jefferson School of Social Change and the National Jewish Congress.

nytimes_articles.headline: Helen Hayes Is Remembered as Star and Woman
nytimes_articles.abstract: Just a few of the friends and admirers of Helen Hayes -- a crowd of some 1,500, in fact -- gathered yesterday in a darkened Broadway theater to say farewell to the diminutive actress whose big-hearted portrayals of regal women helped make her one of the century's best-loved stars.   "What a wonderful sight, a full house -- my mother would have loved it," said James MacArthur, Miss Hayes's son, as he took the stage of the Shubert Theater yesterday afternoon. Mr. MacArthur served as host of a 90-minute tribute that featured encomiums, stories, readings, songs, jokes and vivid remembrances of Miss Hayes, who died of heart failure at age 92 last March.

nytimes_articles.headline: Happy Hour On Hold In Chicago
nytimes_articles.abstract: "Take some of that wood down, take the plywood off the windows," shouted Charles Barkley to the mass of reporters as he entered the locker room after the game. "There ain't gonna be no riots tonight."   A broad smile creased his face. Chicago, it was now expected, would be quiet tonight. There would be no citywide celebration, unruly or otherwise.

nytimes_articles.headline: INSIDE
nytimes_articles.abstract: Planned Parenthood Begins New York Abortion Training   Planned Parenthood of New York has begun training doctors to perform abortions after teaching hospitals have abandoned that role recently in response to social, legal and economic pressures. Page 23. Elusive Peace in Timber War    Both environmentalists and loggers are criticizing the Administration's possible solutions to their battle in the Pacific Northwest. Page 47. Humbling an Unruly General    An Air Force general who disparaged President Clinton was disciplined, very much in public. Page 9. Apple Chairman Alters Role    The chairman of Apple Computer will relinquish his role as chief executive to pursue new alliances. Page 35.

nytimes_articles.headline: Money Talks and Lobbyists Walk
nytimes_articles.abstract: It is 10:30 on a Tuesday night, and the lobbyists who wander in nomadic packs from one fund-raiser to the next have descended on the Scoreboard, an Albany watering hole that is part sports bar and part amusement park.   They already have made the rounds of six other legislative fund-raisers, all within walking distance of the Capitol, making for a busy but not exceptional night. It is a ritual that is fast becoming a dominant feature of political culture in Albany, as in other state capitals, and one that underscores the heightened role played by lobbyists and political action committees. Last Stop: Spring Fling    The last stop of the evening is the Spring Fling, an annual fund-raiser for the Democratic Assembly Campaign Committee, where, for $125, lobbyists can shoot pool, play video golf, curse the Mets and down a few beers with the legislators of their choice.

nytimes_articles.headline: President Chooses an Expert To Halt Smuggling of Aliens
nytimes_articles.abstract: President Clinton moved today to put his stamp on immigration policy, appointing an expert to head the Immigration and Naturalization Service and announcing new initiatives intended to end the smuggling of illegal aliens.   Mr. Clinton nominated Doris M. Meissner, who was a Deputy Associate Attorney General under President Jimmy Carter and an Acting Commissioner of Immigration under President Ronald Reagan, to head the agency. The 51-year-old Ms. Meissner has most recently been director of immigration policy at the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace.

nytimes_articles.headline: Social Worker Attacked at Homeless Center
nytimes_articles.abstract: A social worker at a homeless placement center in lower Manhattan was attacked yesterday, triggering a disturbance that led to the walkout of 20 municipal workers at the office, the police reported.   The disturbance occurred at the Emergency Assistance Center at 80 Catherine Street. Last November, a judge, citing the city's practice of leaving the homeless to sleep in city offices, threatened to order four city officials to spend nights in the center, but the city appealed the order.

nytimes_articles.headline: Smoke in the Prison Cell
nytimes_articles.abstract: Prison inmates may have a constitutional right not to be confined with chain-smoking cellmates, the Supreme Court ruled. Page 8.

nytimes_articles.headline: Firm Is Leaving the Trade Center
nytimes_articles.abstract: Deloitte & Touche, an accounting firm that is one of the World Trade Center's largest tenants, has decided not to move back to the complex.   The firm, the only tenant that never returned to the center after the explosion on Feb. 26, had been considering relocating even before the bombing and said it was not leaving out of dissatisfaction with the Port Authority's response to the disaster.

nytimes_articles.headline: SENATE PANEL VOTE BACKS BUDGET PLAN
nytimes_articles.abstract: On a straight party-line vote, the Senate Finance Committee approved the main elements of a five-year budget package today, the last step before a Senate debate next week that promises to be one of the sharpest partisan clashes in Congress in years.   Laying the ground for that debate, Democratic leaders rushed to a television studio in the Capitol this afternoon to accuse Republicans of blowing hot air about wanting to reduce Government spending more. They observed that the Republicans failed to offer a single amendment in the Finance Committee that would have actually cut spending but did try unsuccessfully to lower taxes on the wealthy.

nytimes_articles.headline: Smith Is Free . . . Well, Sort of Free
nytimes_articles.abstract: Defensive end NEIL SMITH, the Kansas City Chiefs' designated franchise player, is free to negotiate with other National Football League teams, but the Chiefs have the right to match any offer.

nytimes_articles.headline: Bureaucratic Monster, a New Tax Form, Eats Italy
nytimes_articles.abstract: The cartoonists have depicted it as something between a maze and a monster -- a tangle from which there is no escape, a prehistoric carnivore devouring the country. Psychologists have called it the fruit of a pathological obsession by crazed bureaucrats.   Hyperbole? Maybe, especially when the object under comparison is just an annual tax return.

nytimes_articles.headline: Parkway Chase and Shootout Follow Botched Holdup
nytimes_articles.abstract: An armed bank robbery this morning touched off a high-speed 35-minute car chase marked by repeated exchanges of gunfire on some of the busiest highways in Rockland County, N.Y., and Bergen County, N.J.   About 100 shots were fired by the fleeing suspects and the pursuing police over the 30 miles of the chase.  The pursuit began at Pearl River High School in Rockland about 9:15 A.M and ended about 9:50 with the capture of four suspects as they ran from a stolen getaway car into woods beside the Garden State Parkway in this Bergen County suburb, law-enforcement officials said.

nytimes_articles.headline: Finding Stars in a Galaxy of Computers
nytimes_articles.abstract: IN the cosmos of computers, it's hard to determine which is changing more quickly: Hardware capacity or software choices. In either case, if your home computer is only performing word-processing programs and Nintendo, you are missing out on a number of op

nytimes_articles.headline: Look Homeward, Suns: Phoenix Denies Chicago
nytimes_articles.abstract: The city of Chicago was ready to celebrate, but the Phoenix Suns canceled tonight's party.   Avoiding elimination and forcing a return trip to Phoenix, the Suns soundly defeated the Chicago Bulls, 108-98, in Game 5 of the National Basketball Association finals at Chicago Stadium. With the Bulls leading, 3-2, in the four-of-seven-game series, the battle moves to Phoenix for Game 6 on Sunday. Game 7, if necessary, would be played Wednesday night in Phoenix.

nytimes_articles.headline: Tartabull Hears Real Bronx Cheers
nytimes_articles.abstract: The sound was sweet. Danny Tartabull's bat crushed the baseball and it could have been a rocket launching. The sight was stunning. The ball rose rapidly and zoomed into the Yankee bullpen like a bullet. The scene after the mammoth three-run homer produced a Tartabull smile and some overdue satisfaction. It was his first homer at Yankee Stadium this season.   The relentless booing that had plagued Tartabull in the Bronx was transformed into applause for at least one evening because of a memorable 455-foot blast off rookie Eddie Guardado in the first inning, the longest homer at Yankee Stadium this season. Tartabull's first homer in 72 at-bats in the Bronx and his first hit in 16 at-bats created an early cushion, and Jimmy Key and two relievers completed the rest of the equation by squelching the Twins and pacing the Yankees to a 5-0 victory last night.

nytimes_articles.headline: In Peace Plan for Northwest Timber Dispute, Options May Anger Both Sides
nytimes_articles.abstract: In a crucial test of a promise to square environmental goals with economic ones, the Clinton Administration has prepared an array of suggested solutions to end a fractious battle over timber and endangered species in the Pacific Northwest, including one that would slash the amount of cutting on Federal lands in the region by half or more, an Administration official said yesterday.   According to officials in the Administration and staff members in Congress, the options also include a proposal for legislation to bypass or waive some provisions of three important environmental laws, including the National Environmental Policy Act, to hasten the pace for putting the President's timber plan into effect.

nytimes_articles.headline: The Hidden Implications In the Marketing of Pride
nytimes_articles.abstract: PROBABLY you are tired of having possibly crazy people approach you in public places to urge that you worry about things you never heard of, but hang on, have you ever considered the divisive implications of the Ride With Pride regional license plate program of the New York State Motor Vehicles Department?   Under it, since March, motorists who pay $25 extra can acquire plates with any of 11 regional designs along with a designation of the owner's home county or borough. They can, for instance, get one for New York City with a picture of the Brooklyn Bridge or one for Long Island with a picture of a lighthouse.

nytimes_articles.headline: Religion Notes
nytimes_articles.abstract: Sing Sing Theologians     In this season of commencements, most graduates get their diplomas and walk out the door. But the 14 men who received master's degrees from New York Theological Seminary this week still have more time to do. They are all inmates at the Sing Sing Correctional Facility, serving time for armed robbery, murder, drug dealing and other felonies.   The new graduates brought to 147 the number of inmates who have finished the prison program since it was started 10 years ago at the penitentiary. All their training takes place within the prison walls, taught by seminary professors who commute to the fortress-like prison overlooking the Hudson in Ossining, N.Y.

nytimes_articles.headline: No Headline
nytimes_articles.abstract: "It's like income tax. If a loophole is there for the taking, then why not take it?" -- TOM PARSONS, publisher of Best Fares, on ways air travelers beat the published fares.  [ 1:6. ]

nytimes_articles.headline: Turn Diplomas Into Report Cards
nytimes_articles.abstract:
The season of graduation rites is upon us, when our children will be exhorted to ponder lessons from their education and to face doorways to the future. The best lessons, though, may not come from podiums. Consider one from the windows of a lycee I passed recently near the Montparnasse cemetery in Paris.

An imposing stone building, gray and flush to the sidewalk, the lycee hardly resembled a U.S. high school. There were no playing spaces, no courtyards, no parking lots. Across the street, for recreation, was a municipal gym and swimming pool.

What attracted my attention were papers taped to the street-level windows. They were lists of students, but not mere enrollment lists. Rather, beside each name was noted the cumulative judgment of his or her academic performance through the comprehensive examinations given at the end of compulsory schooling in France (when students are 15 or 16 years old). The judgment in the window indicated whether the student had been accepted into the upper level of the lycee. One out of six had been rejected.

nytimes_articles.headline: State Dept. Says President Has Chosen an Israel Envoy
nytimes_articles.abstract: President Clinton has decided to appoint Edward P. Djerejian, who is now Assistant Secretary of State for Near Eastern Affairs, as Ambassador to Israel, a State Department spokesman, Michael McCurry, said today.   Mr. Djerejian, a career Foreign Service officer, who has been Ambassador to Syria, is expected to assume his new post at the end of the year. He has also served in Jordan, Morocco, Lebanon and the Soviet Union.

nytimes_articles.headline: Nigeria Rights Group Cites Opposition's Gains
nytimes_articles.abstract: A Nigerian human rights group defied the military authorities today by publishing what it said were the final results of last Saturday's presidential election.   As expected, the results showed that Moshood Abiola, a wealthy publishing and shipping magnate and the candidate of the Social Democratic Party, had won 19 of the country's 30 states, with 11 going to Bashir Tofa, the standard-bearer of the National Republican Convention.

nytimes_articles.headline: Sports of The Times; Forget It. Suns Beat Knicks in 7.
nytimes_articles.abstract: AS Michael Jordan and the Bulls took the floor last night, one victory away from their prized three-peat, one had to wonder what was going through the mind of the man who owns the copyright for the pithy slogan. Was Pat Riley contemplating the possible bonanza resulting from his business acumen or sadly imagining what might have been had his Knicks stopped the Bulls' championship run at two?   Was Patrick Ewing tuned in as his buddy Jordan attempted to accomplish what Magic Johnson could not, or could he not bring himself to watch?

nytimes_articles.headline: Leonard Dreams in Slow Motion
nytimes_articles.abstract: Justin Leonard had another dream-like round of golf at the United States Open today, but a nightmare threatened to intrude when the amateur and and his esteemed professional partners were warned by officials that they were playing too slowly. A second warning could have resulted in a two-stroke penalty for Leonard, Tom Kite and Nick Faldo.   "I'm learning how to handle pressures like that," said Leonard, who is at even-par 140 and on a pace to produce one of the best Open scores by an amateur in the last 25 years.

nytimes_articles.headline: Badillo's Late Entry Complicates Comptroller Race
nytimes_articles.abstract: The race for New York City comptroller seemed simple two months ago. It was a two-way matchup between Alan G. Hevesi, a little-known Assemblyman from Queens who had some impressive endorsements, and Elizabeth Holtzman, the formidable and battle-scarred incumbent who had been struggling under the weight of a conflict-of-interest investigation.   But the late entry of Herman Badillo has added a volatile element to the race, although Ms. Holtzman retains a heavy advantage in early polls and some political strategists say she is too far in front to be caught.

nytimes_articles.headline: 'Indicators':What They Don't Mean
nytimes_articles.abstract: THEY are shrouded in secrecy impenetrable enough to delight a Cold War-era Kremlinologist. And so they must be: Once the financial markets decide that a certain figure, ratio of figures, or statistic is important enough to be considered an "indicator

nytimes_articles.headline: Kosice Journal; West Disappoints a Slovak Steel Mill
nytimes_articles.abstract: Standing in the vast, Soviet-era steel mill that remains this city's economic heart, Zdeno Velky contemplated a bleak and frustrating future.   "If we can't export to Western Europe and find new markets elsewhere, it will have fatal consequences for our plant," said Mr. Velky, a 25-year-old technician at the factory.

nytimes_articles.headline: Help for the Elderly On Medical Claims
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor:   "Sorting Out the Medical Claims Jumble" (Your Money pages, June 5) illustrates how many people need help to make their way through the maze of medical bills, claim forms and insurance policies.   Many of the elderly and their families or caretakers find it especially difficult to understand their medical insurance needs and medical claims.

nytimes_articles.headline: EMPIRE BLUE CROSS SAYS 2 TOP LEADERS ARE STEPPING DOWN
nytimes_articles.abstract: One month after a major shake-up of the top leadership of Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield, the company announced yesterday that the officials tapped to straighten out Empire had agreed to step down. They are to be replaced by a new, outside management team that has not yet been chosen, the company said.    The announcement came after a hastily called meeting of Empire's board and was in response to the urgings of the New York State Insurance Superintendent, Salvatore R. Curiale. As the state's chief insurance regulator, Mr. Curiale has been under growing pressure to address Empire's escalating financial and management problems and to explain why they were not addressed sooner.

nytimes_articles.headline: Family Bars Exhuming of Connally
nytimes_articles.abstract: The family of former Gov. John B. Connally today angrily rejected requests by F.B.I. officials and private researchers that his body be exhumed in a new search for evidence about the assassination of President John F. Kennedy 30 years ago.    Governor Connally was wounded while riding in a Dallas motorcade with Kennedy when the President was shot to death, and some researchers have suggested that bullet fragments that they say remain in Mr. Connally's body could show once and for all whether a second gun, and presumably a second marksman, might have been involved in the assassination.

nytimes_articles.headline: Corrections
nytimes_articles.abstract: A chart in Business Day yesterday with an economic analysis article about proposed changes in the capital-gains tax misstated the number of returns declaring capital gains in 1991. It was 8,054,000.

nytimes_articles.headline: Editorial Notebook; Supreme Court Strategy
nytimes_articles.abstract: When she questioned the way the Supreme Court decided that women have a constitutional right to choose abortion, Judge Ruth Bader Ginsburg made some pro-choice groups nervous. Their anxiety grew as President Clinton considered her, then chose her to replace retiring Justice Byron White. Whether her doubts about Roe v. Wade -- or some people's doubts about her -- are justified, she pointed up one of the most impressive powers the justices have: the power to choose and shape the issues they decide.    The Supreme Court is the highest law court in the land, but it need not decide every issue pressed upon it. It can call for review of some cases, limit review to one or more issues in a case, hold or ship a case back to a lower court. Judge Ginsburg suggested that in 1973 the Court could have used some of those powers to send the abortion issue on a different legal and political course.

nytimes_articles.headline: A New Name for Winning: Losing
nytimes_articles.abstract: During the mid-1970's, Navy planners studied the prospect of fighting the Soviet Union in the Atlantic and Pacific theaters with a fleet they expected to be half the size of the one that operated during the Vietnam War. Making the best of a bad situation, they devised the "swing strategy." It called for a rapid and successful operation in the Pacific and redeployment of part of the Pacific Fleet to save the day for embattled Atlantic units.   Few naval officers -- and even fewer naval analysts -- took the idea seriously. There were too many unknowns. Would the Soviet Union lose quickly enough in the Pacific? What would be the level of American losses? How would the war unfold in the Atlantic and in Europe? Would the Pacific forces transit safely to the Atlantic? Would they arrive in time or would the war on land have already been decided? No one could answer these questions, though Pentagon operations analysts tried mightily to do so.

nytimes_articles.headline: Family Preservation and Its Victims
nytimes_articles.abstract: Take any floor of a typical low-income housing project. In one apartment, there might be a single woman in her mid-20's with two kids, struggling on a meager welfare check to keep the kids dressed, clean and in school. Down the hall is a family of six. Despite months of looking, Mom works as a maid and Dad, unemployed, does a few odd jobs. At the end of the hall, there is a woman with three kids. She is a heavy crack cocaine user. Her present boyfriend is also her drug supplier, and when he gets angry he hits the kids. Sometimes they lock the kids in the apartment and go off for hours of partying.   The state decides to make life easier for one of these families. Which one? Under welfare laws in Illinois and other states, the mother doing drugs and allowing her boyfriend to belt the kids is the only one entitled to a free housekeeper up to five days a week. She can also receive up to $2,000 for a security deposit and the first month's rent on a new apartment, as well as furniture and up to $500 in cash.

nytimes_articles.headline: NEWS SUMMARY
nytimes_articles.abstract: International 2-5  JAPAN'S GOVERNMENT IS DISSOLVED    Rebel Japanese lawmakers in the ruling party joined the opposition to pass a vote of no confidence in the Government of Kiichi Miyazawa, who then dissolved Parliament and called for elections in July.  1  U.S. ACCEPTS WEAKNESS IN BOSNIA    News analysis: President Clinton's decision to accept the possibility of the ethnic partition of Bosnia reflects a consensus among his advisers that the U.S. is incapable of mediating the war there and unwilling to take military action to stop it.  4    European diplomats turned their focus to the partition of Bosnia.  4    Fighting continued across Bosnia despite another cease-fire.  4  AZERBAIJAN GETS A NEW LEADER    One of the most notorious former officials of the K.G.B. assumed power in Azerbaijan when he announced on television that the former Soviet republic's President had fled to escape advancing rebels.  3  U.N. EXPLAINS ARREST ORDER    U.N. officials in Somalia said that although they had ordered the arrest of a Somali general, the action was intended to keep him in hiding, and they said no special effort which showed that Moshood Abiola, a wealthy businessman, had won 19 of the country's 30 states.  2  CLINTON MEETS JORDAN'S KING    President Clinton and King Hussein of Jordan met for the first time nytimes_articles.headline: Many Mariel Cubans Remain in U.S. Detention
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor:   I am a Cuban-American, who came to the United States seeking freedom in the 1980 Mariel boatlift. I am incarcerated in the Federal Correctional Facility at Fairton, N.J.    I resided in New York City for almost 10 years. During my stay in New York City I remained gainfully employed, although I fell into drug dependency. Consequently, I sold small amounts of drugs, for which I was arrested and received a nine-month jail term in 1989. My jail term terminated in April 1990.

nytimes_articles.headline: 1893: Bells for Victoria : IN OUR PAGES:100, 75 AND 50 YEARS AGO
nytimes_articles.abstract: LONDON - Yesterday [June 21] being the fifty-sixth anniversary of the accession of Queen Victoria, the event was celebrated in London with the customary rejoicing. Bells were rung, flags were hoisted, the usual salutes were fired at the Tower, anda Brigad

nytimes_articles.headline: Theater in Review
nytimes_articles.abstract: Show Me Where The Good Times Are  Jewish Repertory Theater Playhouse 91 316 East 91st Street Manhattan Through June 27 A musical suggested by Moliere's "Imaginary Invalid"; book by Leonora Thuna; music by Kenneth Jacobson; lyrics by Rhoda Roberts; directed by Warren Enters; musical numbers staged by Dennis Grimaldi; set by Bottari & Case; costumes by Hal George; lighting by Michael Baldassari; sound by Scott Stauffer; arrangements by Kenneth Jacobson; musical director, Darren R. WITH: Robert Ari, Gabriel Barre, Donna Ellis, Tim Ewing, Gordon Greenberg, Grace Greig, Tom Gualtieri, Roslyn Kind, Genette Lane, Lauren Mitchell and Roy Alan Wilson.

nytimes_articles.headline: Out of Tour de France, U.S. Team Makes a Vow:'Next Time'
nytimes_articles.abstract: Eddie B. insisted he was not crushed. "I am tough guy," he said. "Long time in this business. I'm not crying." Eddie B. insisted he was not even mad. "I'm not mad, no, I am not." .What exactly was Eddie B. after the Subaru

nytimes_articles.headline: Bridge
nytimes_articles.abstract: What the American Contract Bridge League calls a regional tournament, the smaller American Bridge Association calls a sectional. One of these A.B.A. sectionals was played in St. Louis during the Memorial Day weekend. Dr. Arnold Jones of Hilton Head, S.C., won the Swiss Team Championship teamed with Dorothy Sides of Cincinnati, Alvin Steward and Bobbye Caldwell, both of Chicago.   Jones is a former president of the association and may be due for another year of service. On the diagramed deal he sat South and reached a six-heart contract that became a good bet once West had contributed a light overcall of one spade: the spade finesse was now a virtual certainty. Since hearts was the designated trump suit, North's Roman Key-Card response to Blackwood showed the heart queen and two key cards, the spade ace and the heart king.

nytimes_articles.headline: BRIEFCASE : Lira, Escudo, Peseta Bonds Aim of Lombard Odier Fund
nytimes_articles.abstract: Lombard Odier Investment Management Services, the London-based arm of the eponymous Swiss bank, has launched a mutual fund that invests in Italian, Portuguese and Spanish bonds. .The fund's investment objectives are twofold. The first is to maximize ca

nytimes_articles.headline: Review/Dance; Beneath the Charm of a Work by Mozart
nytimes_articles.abstract: Robin Becker and Company and Ton Simons and Dancers shared a program on Wednesday night as part of the Altogether Different series at the Joyce Theater.    Ms. Becker offered one large-scale work, Mr. Simons three miniatures. His "Divertimento K. 563," a world premiere, proved particularly imaginative. Some choreographers wishing to stage a dance to the Mozart composition Mr. Simons chose might have stressed its superficial charm. Mr. Simons, instead, responded to its underlying states of energy and serenity.

nytimes_articles.headline: Strawberry Returns to the D.L.
nytimes_articles.abstract: DARRYL STRAWBERRY was returned to the disabled list by the Los Angeles Dodgers yesterday, extending his slow recovery from back surgery last September. It is the second time this season that Strawberry has been placed on the 15-day disabled list.   The former slugger for the Mets began suffering serious back problems in May 1992, in his second season with the Dodgers. He played just 43 games last season before undergoing surgery on Sept. 15 to repair a damaged disk in his lower back.

nytimes_articles.headline: Suns Shake and Roll; Bulls Rattle
nytimes_articles.abstract: The scary part for the Bulls tonight was that they came out ready to win their third straight championship, ready to play, but had the play taken away from them by the Phoenix Suns. They couldn't stop a rookie named Richard Dumas. They never had more than a 1-point lead, and that happened just once. They had no way to stop Charles Barkley from the low post and Kevin Johnson from penetrating the lane.   "They certainly rattled us," Michael Jordan said with a sigh after the Suns clouded the Bulls' three-peat plans with a 108-98 victory tonight at Chicago Stadium. "We have two more opportunities to make this happen."

nytimes_articles.headline: From the White House to a Police Station
nytimes_articles.abstract: During the four years he served as the Labor Department's director of immigration policy, Demetrios Papademetriou went to the White House more than a dozen times. But when he arrived today he was arrested, handcuffed, fingerprinted and held for several hours.   Mr. Papademetriou was following a time-honored insiders' tradition when he arrived this morning as part of a group of friends accompanying a new Presidential appointee -- in this case, Doris Meissner, who was about to accept the President's nomination to head the immigration service.

nytimes_articles.headline: President and King Hussein Meet as Iraq Issue Lingers
nytimes_articles.abstract: President Clinton and King Hussein of Jordan met for the first time today in a friendly session, but there remained signs that their two countries have not yet mended some differences left over from the Persian Gulf war.   The two leaders proclaimed a shared commitment to the Middle East peace talks, and both vowed to seek "tangible progress" this year. Their meeting was nevertheless also notable for its absence of an American gesture of forgiveness: the release of tens of millions of dollars in aid withheld from Jordan as punishment for its wartime support for Iraq.

nytimes_articles.headline: Critic's Notebook; Early-Music Lovers Go Back to Their First Love
nytimes_articles.abstract: The defenders of mainstream music making are not alone in wondering whether the early music movement's encroachment into the Romantic repertory is for the best. Some people in early music circles also have misgivings on the ground that this musical doctrine of Manifest Destiny is stealing attention and energy from the study and revival of real early music, the works of medieval, Renaissance and Baroque masters.   That concern is being addressed here this week at the seventh Boston Early Music Festival and Exhibition, which assembles every two years. After exploring the late Classical era in recent years, the festival set aside the newfangled stuff and returned to the movement's roots. This year's program is devoted mainly to music of the late 16th and early 17th centuries, when Renaissance styles gave way to Baroque innovations. Its modernist edge is a concert of Colonial and 19th-century American hymns and ballads to be given by the Boston Camerata on Saturday evening. But the festival's centerpiece is Monteverdi's "Orfeo" in a scholarly approximation of a period staging.

nytimes_articles.headline: Corrections
nytimes_articles.abstract: An article on Wednesday about the Middle East peace talks referred incorrectly in some editions to the spokeswoman for the Palestinian delegation. She is Hanan Ashrawi.

nytimes_articles.headline: Article 977093 -- No Title
nytimes_articles.abstract: After years of planning to rebuild the Times Square subway stop as part of a massive redevelopment project in the area, the Transit Authority has instead decided that it should not wait any longer to begin fixing the station itself.   The authority yesterday unveiled a design for a $130 million reconstruction of the station, which is the city's busiest, with 470,000 passengers using it daily.

nytimes_articles.headline: Anti-Defamation League Investigates Extremists of All Stripes
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor:   Dennis King and Chip Berlet, in their polemic against the Anti-Defamation League, attack us for views we do not hold and published statements we have not written ("The A.D.L. Under Fire," Op-Ed, May 28).    The two allege that Irwin Suall told them 10 years ago that the chief danger to American Jews was the American left, that right-wing extremism in the United States was insignificant and that to focus on it would be a "dangerous diversion from the struggle against Communism." The authors also allege that Mira Boland, writing in The Wall Street Journal, "suggested that anyone who regarded 'violent racism' as a major problem was indulging in 'paranoid fantasy' or subversive propaganda." Neither of us has ever made any such statement or suggestion.

nytimes_articles.headline: Planned Parenthood of New York Begins Abortion Training
nytimes_articles.abstract: Planned Parenthood of New York began training doctors yesterday to perform abortions, a role that teaching hospitals have abandoned in recent years in response to social, legal and economic pressures.   Over the last decade the number of medical residency programs that require abortion training in the United States has dropped by half, and that drop is one reason most of the nation's counties do not have a single doctor who will perform the procedure.

nytimes_articles.headline: Success on Ice: Islanders Raise Ticket Prices
nytimes_articles.abstract: The surprising success of the Islanders is being followed by an eye-opening increase in the price of their tickets. Season-subscription holders will pay as much as $7 more a game, according to a letter recently sent by the team. Prices for individual tickets sold for single games have not yet been announced.   Rates for season seats will increase as follows: tickets that cost $26.50 last season will go up to $32; $22 tickets will be raised, depending on location, to $26 or $29, and $16 tickets will increase to $20.

nytimes_articles.headline: Spain Paying $350 Million for Baron's Art
nytimes_articles.abstract: After a year of complicated negotiations, the Spanish Government today announced an agreement to buy the prized art collection of the Swiss industrialist Baron Hans Heinrich Thyssen-Bornemisza for $350 million.   The collection of 775 paintings from the 13th to the 20th centuries is considered one of the world's greatest private art collections, perhaps surpassed only by that of Queen Elizabeth II. Sotheby's has estimated its value at nearly $2 billion.

nytimes_articles.headline: Top Navy Officer Criticizes Plan to Cut Carriers
nytimes_articles.abstract: In another public disagreement between the military and the Clinton Administration, the Chief of Naval Operations today criticized Defense Secretary Les Aspin's emerging plan to reduce the number of aircraft carriers to 10 from 12.   The Navy's top-ranking officer, Adm. Frank B. Kelso 2d, told reporters that the reduction would hurt the country's ability to respond quickly to regional crises and to provide a hedge against conflicts in peacetime. The Navy has 14 carriers in service; two are scheduled to be retired this year.

nytimes_articles.headline: TRUCE FAILS TO END FIGHTING IN BOSNIA
nytimes_articles.abstract: Fighting continued across this war-torn country hours after the latest countrywide cease-fire was scheduled to have taken effect today, local radio reports and United Nations officials said.    The Bosnian Government's radio station said Serbian forces in eastern Bosnia had breached Muslim defenses around the encircled city of Gorazde, which has been the target of a three-week-old Serbian offensive. But United Nations military monitors in the town made no mention of a breakthrough, and even if it is confirmed, there was no way to assess the severity of the setback for the Muslim defenders.

nytimes_articles.headline: Two Patriots Are Stabbed
nytimes_articles.abstract: Running back LEONARD RUSSELL of the New England Patriots was in guarded but stable condition after he and teammate TIM EDWARDS were stabbed early yesterday after an argument with two other men outside a club in Boston, the police said.   Russell was in Massachusetts General Hospital's intensive-care unit after suffering a stab wound under the armpit that went into his chest. "It missed the heart, but he did bleed fairly seriously," said hospital spokesman MARTIN BANDER.

nytimes_articles.headline: Mr. Clinton: Don't Bury Bosnia
nytimes_articles.abstract: Seeing that no outside power means to deny it total military victory, Serbia now drops all pretense. Yes, its real goal is to destroy and dismember Bosnia, not merely to protect the interests of Bosnian Serbs. Yes, it fully intends to keep most of the territory it has forcibly seized and to turn it into an ethnically cleansed Serbian state. And yes, it is happy to parcel out most of the rest to its sometime enemy, sometime ally Croatia.    As for the Bosnian Government, the Serbs and Croats generously offer it full title to two tiny pockets of leftover mostly-Muslim territory, provided it signs on to the partition plan right away.

nytimes_articles.headline: Coup in Guatemala Nothing Like Peru's
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor:   In "Guatemala: Democracy Recouped?" (editorial, June 3), you presuppose an automatic similarity between the political process in Guatemala and Peru without attempting at least a cursory evaluation of the specific conditions in each country.   The outcome of events in Guatemala has already proved that the parallelism drawn was clearly wrong. President Alberto Fujimori of Peru has stated that the circumstances of the two countries are different, that the concrete situation of Peru does not lend itself to a facile comparison with any other country and that it should not serve as a model. He also stated that the destiny of Guatemala was, as it ought to be, in the hands of the Guatemalan people.

nytimes_articles.headline: Sampras May Sit Out Wimbledon
nytimes_articles.abstract: PETE SAMPRAS, the world's top-ranked player, said yesterday that a shoulder injury makes him questionable for Wimbledon, which starts Monday.

nytimes_articles.headline: Court Offers Inmates a Way To Escape Prison Smokers
nytimes_articles.abstract: Prison inmates who can show that exposure to cigarette smoke is a threat to their health may have a constitutional right not to be confined with a chain-smoking cellmate, the Supreme Court ruled today.   While the Court stopped short of declaring a constitutional right to a smoke-free prison, the 7-to-2 decision offered a notably generous interpretation of the Eighth Amendment's prohibition against cruel and unusual punishment.

nytimes_articles.headline: General Ousted for Derisive Remarks About President
nytimes_articles.abstract: In the political equivalent of a public execution, the Air Force Chief of Staff took the unusual step today of holding a news conference to announce that a two-star Air Force general who had made disparaging remarks about President Clinton would be fined and forced to retire.    Gen. Merrill A. McPeak, the Air Force chief, said that Maj. Gen. Harold N. Campbell, who called President Clinton a "dope smoking," "skirt chasing," "draft dodging" commander in chief, would be fined $7,000 and would retire on July 1. An official letter of reprimand will also be placed in the file of the 53-year-old general.

nytimes_articles.headline: CHRONICLE
nytimes_articles.abstract: What happens when you put ROSEANNE ARNOLD, ROGER CLINTON, RICHARD VIGUERIE and ALEXANDRA PENNEY in the same room? "Comedic mayhem" was one way to describe it, said FRANK GANNON, whose idea it was to assemble this eclectic group: the comedian, the President's singing half brother, the direct-mail and fund-raising expert of the political right and the editor in chief of Self magazine. They made up a panel for a new cable television talk show called "Politically Incorrect," billed as a "McLaughlin Group" with humor. The weekly series, which goes on the air on July 25 on the Comedy Central cable network, is produced by HBO Downtown Productions.   "It was the most ill-assorted bunch, like a crazy quilt of people," said Ms.  Penney, whose new book, "How to Make Love to a Man (Safely)" was recently published by a Crown imprint. "But a quilt is sewn together, and this was fission."

nytimes_articles.headline: Murder by AIDS Is Easy Answer
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor:   "AIDS and a Dentist's Secrets" (The Week in Review, June 6) states that some are asking whether the cluster of cases of human immunodeficiency virus (the virus that causes AIDS) transmitted from a dentist in Florida to six patients should not be considered "murder."   I was medical counsel to Kimberly Bergalis and am medical counsel to Sherry Johnson, the sixth patient infected from Dr. David J. Acer. I have been as intimately involved with these cases as anyone, and believe that attempts to solve this mystery with a murder theory fly in the face of what is known about infectious diseases and blood-born viruses. The medical facts are these:

nytimes_articles.headline: Japan's Government Falls; Party in Peril
nytimes_articles.abstract: In a revolt that could end nearly four decades of one-party rule in Japan, rebel legislators in the party of Prime Minister Kiichi Miyazawa joined forces with the opposition Friday night to pass a vote of no confidence in Mr. Miyazawa's Government. The Prime Minister then dissolved Parliament and called for elections next month.    The organizers of the rebellion, which turned on the question of how to reform Japan's scandal-plagued Government, appeared to be preparing to split off from the ruling Liberal Democratic Party. Their moves raised the prospect of a fundamental reorganization of the political order that has ruled Japan since the Liberal Democratic Party was founded in 1955.

nytimes_articles.headline: Aikman Reportedly to Have Surgery
nytimes_articles.abstract: Dallas Cowboys quarterback TROY AIKMAN will have surgery today in Los Angeles for a herniated disk, according to a broadcast report.

nytimes_articles.headline: Service for Algernon Black
nytimes_articles.abstract: A memorial service for Algernon D. Black, leader emeritus of the New York Society for Ethical Culture, will be held at 2 P.M. tomorrow in the society's Meeting House, 2 East 64th Street at the corner of Central Park West. Mr. Black died on May 9 at a nursing home in Rye, N.Y. He was 92.

nytimes_articles.headline: There's Lots of Blue Among the Greens
nytimes_articles.abstract: It has become a fact of sporting life: fear of terrorists and random acts of violence. But the verdant, leisurely environment of a golf tournament is hardly the place to expect Super Bowl- or Olympic-type security.   Yet two S.W.A.T. teams and a helicopter are on standby alert for the United States Open at the Baltusrol Golf Club, according to a Springfield police detective.

nytimes_articles.headline: U.N. Warns Iraq on Its Ban Of Cameras at Weapon Sites
nytimes_articles.abstract: The Security Council warned Iraq today of "serious consequences" if it continued to reject the installation of video cameras at weapons sites and to refuse the transfer of chemical weapons equipment to a destruction site.   The statement came after a meeting with the head of the commission charged with destroying Iraq's chemical weapons, Rolf Ekeus.

nytimes_articles.headline: Barking Up the Wrong Tree in the Senate
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor:   "Cold Feet in the Senate," your June 6 editorial lamenting the Senate's continued refusal to enact campaign finance reform, reminds me of the exhortations of dog owners who urge their pets to stop barking. "Fido, stop barking!" is the logical equivalent of "Fido, stop being a dog!" Your exhortations to incumbent members of Congress to enact campaign finance reform is like urging politicians not to be politicians.   Having ignored these futile appeals for at least a decade, Congress will predictably ignore them in the future. In your benighted opposition to term limits, you present campaign finance reform as an alternative. But term limitation is not at all an alternative. It is indeed a precondition for campaign-finance reform.

nytimes_articles.headline: Bishops Pass Resolution Warning Against Abortion in Health Plan
nytimes_articles.abstract: The nation's Roman Catholic bishops passed a resolution today underscoring their previous warnings that abortion coverage could jeopardize passage of a national health-care plan.   "As longtime advocates of health-care reforms, we appeal to the leaders of the nation to avoid a divisive and polarizing dispute," the bishops said in a resolution passed late today at the semiannual meeting of the National Conference of Catholic Bishops. "The common good is not advanced when advocates of so-called 'choice' compel taxpayers to fund what we and many others are convinced is the destruction of human life."

nytimes_articles.headline: New York's Troubled Giant
nytimes_articles.abstract: Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield is the largest of a network of 71 independent, nonprofit companies that provide health insurance to 68 million Americans in all 50 states. The first of the plans was formed 60 years ago as a way for people to pay in advance for hospital care.   Blue Cross plans cover hospital costs, while Blue Shield plans pay doctors' bills. In many areas, like New York, the plans are operated by one nonprofit corporation.

nytimes_articles.headline: CHRONICLE
nytimes_articles.abstract: Repentant and resplendent, ELTON JOHN took to the stage in Tel Aviv on Thursday night, two days after he made a hasty departure from Israel, canceling a concert because he had been kept waiting by passport officials and mobbed by a crowd at his hotel.    Wearing silver-studded white tails and black pants, Mr. John, 46, performed before a wildly cheering crowd of 35,000 in Yarkon Park, The Associated Press reported yesterday. He said: "I'd like to apologize. In the long run, we're here, and that's where we want to be. Thank you for your patience. Now let's get on with it."

nytimes_articles.headline: Theater in Review
nytimes_articles.abstract: Prime Time Prophet  Players Theater 115 Macdougal Street Greenwich Village  Music and lyrics by Kevin Connors; book by Randy Buck; directed by Kevin Connors; set by Don Jensen; lighting by John Michael Deegan; costumes by David Robinson; musical direction and vocal arrangements by David Wolfson; production stage manager, James Schilling. Presented by the Prophet Company Limited. WITH: Janet Aldrich, David Brand, Beth Glover, Jonathan Hadley and Marcus Maurice.

nytimes_articles.headline: Court Says Government May Pay For Interpreter in Religious School
nytimes_articles.abstract: The Supreme Court ruled today that the Constitution permits using government money to pay for a sign-language interpreter to accompany a deaf child to a parochial school.   The 5-to-4 decision marked the first time in decades of constitutional debate over aid to parochial schools that the Court has allowed a public employee to be part of a religious school's instructional program.

nytimes_articles.headline: Europeans Turn to Partition of Bosnia
nytimes_articles.abstract: Conceding that the United Nations-European Community peace plan for Bosnia is effectively dead, European diplomats turned today to a new proposal for a three-way partition of the country but emphasized that they did so reluctantly.   They admitted that the idea of carving the country into three parts, as Serbia and Croatia are proposing in negotiations in Geneva, had moved to the fore and, as one put it, "acquired a certain momentum."

nytimes_articles.headline: 1918:Allied Godparents : IN OUR PAGES:100, 75 AND 50 YEARS AGO
nytimes_articles.abstract: FRENCH FRONT - The religious confirmation of the new national Polish army born a few months ago took place yesterday [June 17] in the presence of representatives of the United States, Great Britain, France and Italy, acting as godparents. The occasion was

nytimes_articles.headline: Young 1 From Record With 22d Loss in Row
nytimes_articles.abstract: Just what the Mets need -- more exposure. Local television teams swarmed the clubhouse tonight. A national cable outfit was there. The numbers of reporters had grown exponentially. It was not unlike some disaster scene.   Anthony Young was pitching, and win or lose, it was going to be a big story. Young lost. His streak of consecutive defeats is at 22. The cameras and microphones aren't going anywhere any time soon.

nytimes_articles.headline: 1943:Steinbeck Reports : IN OUR PAGES:100, 75 AND 50 YEARS AGO
nytimes_articles.abstract: NEW YORK - [From our New York edition:] John Steinbeck, the distinguished novelist and playwright, has arrived in England on an assignment as war correspondent for the New York Herald Tribune. His first dispatch, describing life on a crowded troops transp

nytimes_articles.headline: More by Bernstein
nytimes_articles.abstract: The New York Philharmonic Ensembles series ends its season tomorrow with an all-Bernstein program at 3 P.M. at Merkin Concert Hall, 129 West 67th Street, Manhattan. The works to be performed are the Sonata for Clarinet and Piano, Arias and Barcaroles, Sonata for Violin and Piano and music from "West Side Story" arranged for brass quintet. The program is part of "A Philharmonic Celebration: Remembering Lenny." Tickets are $12. Information: (212) 362-8719.

nytimes_articles.headline: Navy Defines Sexual Harassment With the Colors of Traffic Lights
nytimes_articles.abstract: Washington is famous for its ominous reds -- red tape, red ink, the red phone. Now there is also the red zone, the Navy's effort to offer simple, "bumper sticker" instructions on curbing sexual harassment.   With a few succinct phrases, recently sent to all commanding officers in a quarterly information packet called the "Captain's Call Kit," the Department of the Navy tries to answer a question that has obsessed and confounded the nation since the Navy's Tailhook scandal and Capitol Hill's Anita Hill-Clarence Thomas hearings: "What Is Sexual Harassment?"

nytimes_articles.headline: Sports of The Times; John Daly Reaches The Unreachable Green
nytimes_articles.abstract: LEE TREVINO likes to joke that, when caught in a thunder-and-lightning storm, a golfer should hold a 1-iron aloft. "Not even God," he says, "can hit a 1-iron."   But John Daly can.

nytimes_articles.headline: Corrections
nytimes_articles.abstract: Because of an editing error, a brief report in some editions of Business Day yesterday about the appointment of Donald B. Reed as president and chief executive of the New England Telephone Corporation misstated Mr. Reed's tenure. He has worked at the company for 27 years.

nytimes_articles.headline: Excerpts From the Court's Decision on Health Risk to Inmates
nytimes_articles.abstract: Following are excerpts from the Supreme Court's decision today that prison inmates may have the right to be free of a smoke-filled environment that would endanger their health. Justice Byron R. White wrote the majority opinion, Helling v. McKinney, which was joined by Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist and Justices Harry A. Blackmun, John Paul Stevens, Sandra Day O'Connor, Anthony M. Kennedy and David H. Souter. Justice Clarence Thomas's dissenting opinion was joined by Justice Antonin Scalia. FROM THE DECISION  By Justice White    This case requires us to decide whether the health risk posed by involuntary exposure of a prison inmate to environmental tobacco smoke (E.T.S.) can form the basis of a claim for relief under the Eighth Amendment.

nytimes_articles.headline: Campaign Finance Reform: Alive
nytimes_articles.abstract: The Senate's campaign finance reform bill isn't nearly as strong as the package recommended by President Clinton and Senate Democratic leaders. It leaves big holes that will need filling when the measure gets to conference with the House. That it passed at all, however, is a victory worth savoring. There was ferocious Republican opposition and stratospheric nervousness about campaign reform on both sides of the aisle.    Ignoring scandals and public disgust at corrupt and distracting campaign fund raising, Republicans have blocked meaningful change since 1974. The Senate majority leader, George Mitchell, deserves credit for breaking this gridlock with a difficult victory that keeps reform alive. Seven Republicans -- James Jeffords of Vermont, William Cohen of Maine, John Chafee of Rhode Island, Nancy Kassebaum of Kansas, Larry Pressler of South Dakota, Dave Durenberger of Minnesota and John McCain of Arizona -- provided the crucial votes needed to break the Republican filibuster.

nytimes_articles.headline: Janzen Watches the Birdies Fall and Ties an Open Record
nytimes_articles.abstract: With a burst of birdies through the heart of Baltusrol's back nine, Lee Janzen shot his second consecutive 67 today to take a two-stroke lead in the 93d United States Open.   Propelled by a hot 3-2-3 run on the 11th, 12th and 13th holes, the 28-year-old Janzen finished with a 36-hole total of six-under-par 134, two strokes better than Tom Watson and Payne Stewart.

nytimes_articles.headline: BRIEFCASE : Robert Fleming & Co. Floats Gold Warrants in Hong Kong
nytimes_articles.abstract: The investment house Robert Fleming & Co. has floated a series of call warrants on the price of gold. The warrants - highly volatile securities that will soar in price if the gold price increases but will be worthless if it does not - are to trade in

nytimes_articles.headline: Ex-K.G.B. Aide Grabs Helm in Baku
nytimes_articles.abstract: One of the most notorious former officials of the K.G.B. formally assumed power in Azerbaijan today when he went on television to announce that the country's President had fled the capital to escape advancing rebels.   The new leader, Heydar Aliyev, said he "could not forgive" the President, Abulfez Elchibey, for abandoning his office in Azerbaijan's hour of need. He also faulted the Elchibey Government in the current crisis for attempting to disarm military units that refused to obey the central command.

nytimes_articles.headline: Auerbach Undergoes Heart Surgery
nytimes_articles.abstract: Celtics President RED AUERBACH underwent open-heart surgery yesterday at Massachusetts General Hospital in Boston, said MARTIN BANDER, a medical center spokesman.

nytimes_articles.headline: Corrections
nytimes_articles.abstract: A sports chart yesterday, giving a hole-by-hole stroke analysis for the first-round leaders in the United States Open golf tournament, misstated the par totals for the first nine and last nine holes. They are 34 and 36, not 35 and 35.

nytimes_articles.headline: METRO DIGEST
nytimes_articles.abstract: TOP BLUE CROSS OFFICIALS QUIT  The two top officials of Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield have agreed to step down so that they can be replaced by new management with no connection to the problems that have roiled the company in recent months. At a hastily called meeting, Empire's board bowed to pressure from the New York State Insurance Superintendent, Salvatore R. Curiale, and voted to search quickly for replacements for Harold E. Vogt, the company's chairman, and Donald L. Morchower, the acting chief executive. They have been in the jobs for only one month. Page 1. NEW YORK CITY MORE ANGLES IN CAMPAIGN  The race for New York City comptroller seemed simple two months ago. It was a two-way matchup between Alan G. Hevesi, a little-known Assemblyman from Queens who had some impressive endorsements, and Elizabeth Holtzman, the formidable and battle-scarred incumbent who had been struggling under the weight of a conflict-of-interest investigation. But the late entry of Herman Badillo has added a volatile element to the race. Page 25.  TIMES SQUARE STATION TO BE RENOVATED  After years of planning to rebuild the Times Square subway stop as part of a huge redevelopment project in the area, the Transit Authority has instead decided that it should not wait any longer to begin fixing the station itself. The authority has unveiled a design for a $130 million reconstruction of the station, which is the city's busiest. Page 25.  FIRM WON'T RETURN TO TRADE CENTER  Deloitte & Touche, an accounting firm that is one of the World Trade Center's largest tenants, has decided not to move back to the complex. The firm, the only tenant that never physically returned to the center after the explosion on Feb. 26, had been strongly considering relocating even before the bombing and said it was not leaving out of dissatisfaction with the Port Authority's response to the disaster. Page 25. REGION  WILD CHASE AFTER ROBBERY  An armed bank robbery touched off a high-speed, 35-minute car chase marked by repeated exchanges of gunfire on some of the busiest highways in Rockland County, N.Y., and Bergen County, N.J. About 100 shots were fired by the fleeing suspects and the pursuing police over the 30 miles of the chase. The pursuit began at Pearl River High School about 9:15 A.M and ended about 11 A.M. with the capture of four suspects as they ran from a stolen getaway car into woods beside the Garden State Parkway in the Bergen County suburb of Washington Township, officials said. Page 26.  CIVIL-RIGHTS CHARGES DROPPED  Federal prosecutors in Camden, N.J., dropped civil rights charges against two men three days before their retrial in the beating of an Asian Indian physician. Judge Joseph E. Irenas of Federal District Court said that prosecutors did their duty in trying to prove that the attack was racially motivated. The second trial for Mark Evangelista, a 23-year-old Hudson County police officer who lives in Jersey City, and Martin Riccardi, 26, of North Plainfield, was scheduled to start on Monday. A third defendant was acquitted on May 28. The three were accused of beating Dr. Kaushal Sharan in the Heights section of Jersey City in September 1987. Page 26. About New York by Michael T. Kaufman 25

nytimes_articles.headline: Corrections
nytimes_articles.abstract: A report in the Garden Q.& A. column of The Home Section on Thursday about landscape fabrics misstated the dimensions of one product, Weedblock. A 4-by-50-foot roll costs about $20, and a 6-by-50-foot roll about $30.

nytimes_articles.headline: A New Light on Empire's Finances
nytimes_articles.abstract: The subject, to the ears of many, was about as boring as a subject could be: insurance, and the more arcane aspects of insurance at that.   But the passion in the wood-paneled hearing room of the state Legislative Office Building in Albany was palpable. Two top officials of Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield were pleading their case for sweeping changes in the state insurance system. The fate of the nation's largest nonprofit health insurer was at stake, they said.

nytimes_articles.headline: Review/Television; Music as the Food of Hate: Rock for the Skinheads
nytimes_articles.abstract: The subject is riveting and downright frightening. It's "hate rock," sometimes called "Oi!," a racism-and-violence virus in pop music that has become an international infection. And who better to examine the phenomenon than MTV, pop music's global showcase? This week -- showings are tonight at 10:30 and tomorrow night at 9:30 -- MTV does give it a good try. But the upshot is an unsettling clash between form and content.    "Hate Rock: An MTV News Special Report," produced as part of a "Free Your Mind" series, goes to parts of Europe, Canada and the United States, along the way providing a sketchy history of skinheads. Origins, we are told, go back to the punk scene in England of the 1970's. In Germany, particularly after the 1989 collapse of Communism and the Berlin Wall, the neo-Nazi youth movement and music groups like Radikahl have become more prominent, especially as antagonism toward foreigners grows. In Florida, we are shown interviews with beer-swilling members of groups like White Aryan Resistance.

nytimes_articles.headline: U.N. Denies It Is Seeking Somali Clan Leader's Arrest
nytimes_articles.abstract: Senior United Nations military officials said today that although they had put out an arrest warrant for a Somali clan leader, the warrant was intended mostly to keep him in hiding and away from his supporters.    They said that unless United Nations troops accidentally came across the clan leader, Gen. Mohammed Farah Aidid, they would mount no special operation to capture him.

nytimes_articles.headline: A Clinton Quip Is Just a Quip? Not So, Say New Zealanders
nytimes_articles.abstract: The spokesman for the New Zealand Embassy was diplomatic, the ambassador discreet. But other New Zealanders here today were miffed about the way President Clinton brushed off a major issue in their homeland.   When asked at the news conference on Thursday night about resolving an eight-year impasse over the refusal of New Zealand to allow American nuclear warships to use its ports, Mr. Clinton quipped: "I've given absolutely no thought to that question. And I'm afraid if I give an answer to it I'll be in more trouble tomorrow than I can figure out."

nytimes_articles.headline: Review/Dance; Making Gravity Disappear
nytimes_articles.abstract: Gina Gibney's "Incidence of Light," a world premiere, got the evening off to a promising but dauntingly portentous start on Thursday night in the Altogether Different festival at the Joyce Theater. Dancers formed and re-formed into couples, dressed in shades of yellow-gold and bathed in golden light, with each pairing framed by blackouts. The dancers moved before an architectural set consisting of three monolithic shapes that looked as if they had strayed from a Futurist painting. The mood was a little sad. There was less a sense of encounters than of partings and of loss.    Then the stage opened up and grew lighter. The set elements had disappeared, one by one, during the blackouts. And Ms. Gibney's superb dancers, constrained before, whirled through the open space as if traction and gravity did not exist. But there was a sense of purposelessness to it all. Nothing looked motivated. Ms. Gibney is good at creating carefully plotted and intelligently worked dance. She knows how to unspool high-energy movement so it looks emotionally inevitable. But the latter gift failed her here.

nytimes_articles.headline: TRANSACTIONS
nytimes_articles.abstract: Baseball American League  NEW YORK YANKEES -- Signed Paul Gibson, pitcher, to a minor-league contract with Columbus of the International League.

nytimes_articles.headline: High Court Decides 16 States Owe Federal Retirees for Illegal Taxes
nytimes_articles.abstract: A Supreme Court decision today made a four-year-old tax ruling by the Justices retroactive and raised the possibility that 16 states would have to pay huge tax refunds to retired Federal workers who did not get a tax break that the states gave their own retired employees.   The Court left it up to those states to come up with a remedy. Depending on state law, alternatives to a lump-sum refund, like future tax credits, might be available. But the 7-to-2 ruling was clearly a blow to states that had hoped to avoid any liability, including New York, which had prevailed on the question in a recent state court ruling.

nytimes_articles.headline: Results Plus
nytimes_articles.abstract: TENNIS A Try for Her 164th Top-seeded Martina Navratilova won her semifinal match in the Eastbourne grass-court tournament in England yesterday and will try for her 164th career title against a player who has never been to a final before. Navratilova, a 10-time champion at Eastbourne, was a 6-1, 6-3 winner over fellow American Patty Fendick. The nine-time Wimbledon champion will play Miriam Oremans of the Netherlands for the Volkswagen Cup today. Oremans upset defending champion Lori McNeil, 7-6 (9-7), 7-6 (7-3). McNeil was playing her second match of the day, earlier defeating Nathalie Tauziat, 6-1, 7-5, in the quarterfinals of the rain-plagued tournament. Oremans kept the pressure on the ninth-seeded McNeil by charging the net at every opportunity, including on her second serve. It was a tactic that gave the 20-year-old Dutch player, who had ousted fourth-seeded Helena Sukova in the quarterfinals, the edge in the tie breakers. (AP) Stark Advances to Semifinals: Unseeded Jonathan Stark moved into the semifinals of the Halle Open in Germany by beating 18-year-old Hendrik Dreekmann, 6-4, 7-6 (7-5), yesterday and ending the German's string of upsets. The next opponent for Stark will be top-seeded Andrei Medvedev, playing in only his second grass-court tournament. He outlasted Jonas Svensson, 5-7, 6-3, 6-4, in a rain-delayed match completed yesterday. Henri Leconte also gained the semifinals by fighting off two match points to slip by Richey Reneberg, 6-2, 3-6, 7-6 (10-8). He will play second-seeded Petr Korda, who routed Karsten Braasch of Germany, 6-1, 6-2.   The 18-year-old Medvedev, seeking to adjust his game to grass before Wimbledon next week, has soared into the top-10 ranking after a clay-court season that he topped last month by reaching the semifinals of the French Open. In his only previous grass-court tournament, he lost in the second round at Rosmalen, the Netherlands, two weeks ago. (AP) All-Australian Final in Manchester: Wally Masur and Jason Stoltenberg won their semifinal matches in the Direct Line Insurance Manchester Open and set up an all-Australian final for the grass-court tournament. The fourth-seeded Masur dispatched second-seeded Henrik Holm of Sweden, 6-4, 6-7 (4-7), 7-6 (7-5), and Stoltenberg beat Stephane Simian of France, 6-7 (6-8), 6-2, 6-3. The two Australians have met three times, and the 23-year-old Stoltenberg is still looking for his first victory over the veteran Masur. (AP) FOOTBALL Miners Hit Pay Dirt The first United States franchise to play in the Canadian Football League had a successful debut Thursday night as the Sacramento Gold Miners beat the Winnipeg Blue Bombers, 21-15, in an exhibition game in Winnipeg. The Gold Miners, who were added to the league in February, fielded a team of just American players. Pete Hamm caught two touchdown passes for Sacramento -- an 11-yarder from David Archer in the second quarter and a 13-yarder from Kerwin Bell in the third. Winnipeg quarterback Matt Dunigan and Sacramento defensive end Randy Thorton were ejected 2 minutes 11 seconds into the game. Dunigan lost his cool after a late hit, ripped the helmet off a Gold Miners' player and threw the headgear 50 yards down the field. Another proposed United States expansion team -- the San Antonio Texans -- folded because of financial trouble. (AP)

nytimes_articles.headline: Theme Schools Face Hurdles In Opening
nytimes_articles.abstract: As they race to open more than 30 small experimental public schools in the fall, New York City educators say they are grappling with an array of difficulties -- from hiring directors to finding buildings to signing up students.   Four of the 37 small new schools will not open in September as originally planned, school officials said yesterday. All four will instead open in the fall of 1994.

nytimes_articles.headline: Survival of Symphonies: Radical Changes Urged
nytimes_articles.abstract: One year ago, the American Symphony Orchestra League took its own pulse and did not like what it found. Bad news about American orchestras, their finances, their audiences and their musical operations had been trickling in piecemeal for years. The so-called Wolf report, a study commissioned by the league, documented what most had long suspected.   The Wolf report also inspired a task force of 150 people within and outside the music world. They have been meeting over the last year, addressing issues like repertory, labor relations, community life, cultural diversity, education, volunteerism, fund raising and management.

nytimes_articles.headline: Tolbert's Victory Prevents a Devers Sweep
nytimes_articles.abstract: Hurdles, real and conceptual, were in the way. All were cleared tonight, by national champions Lynda Tolbert and Jack Pierce at the USA/Mobil championships.   At a hot and humid Hayward Field, Tolbert overcame favorite Gail Devers, plus medical problems that included a torn hamstring, stress fractures in both her feet and chronic anemia. She edged Devers in a photo finish, winning the women's 100-meter hurdles in 12.72 seconds to foil a historic attempt at a double by her more famous rival.
